newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan unit says Apple to keep strong identity.
newsitem.headline: Japan unit says Apple to keep strong identity.

text.p: Apple Computer Inc's Japanese unit said on Thursday that the identity of its parent company would remain strong despite a tie-up with Microsoft Corp.
Meanwhile, Japanese personal computer makers said they were still evaluating the impact of the surprise move on the domestic market and would continue to watch developments closely.
"Yesterday's announcement (on Apple's tie-up with Microsoft) does not mean at all that Apple has been taken over," said Eiko Harada, president of Apple's Japanese unit.
Harada said Apple will focus on a business strategy that will bring out its originality, addressing concerns among avid Japanese fans of Macintosh computers.
Harada also said the tie-up ensures further growth of Apple Computer's business and would not bring any change in how Apple conducted business in Japan.
On Wednesday, Apple Computer and Microsoft announced a broad product and technology development agreement.
Under the deal, Microsoft will invest $150 million in non-voting stock of the troubled PC maker.
Microsoft will also develop more programmes for the Macintosh, including future versions of its Office software, Internet Explorer browser and other software.
Concurrently, Apple also replaced all but two of its directors, but stopped short of naming a new chairman of the board.
"It was surprising to hear Microsoft offering a hand to Apple to prop up its long-time rival," said a spokesman for NEC Corp, Japan's top personal computer maker.

"Nevertheless, Microsoft will be able to expand the market for its application software through the tie-up," the spokesman said. "In the long term, Microsoft's Windows (operating system) may also be improved with technology employed from Apple."
A spokesman for Fujitsu Ltd said the company had yet to fully evaluate the impact of the tie-up on the Japanese PC market, but that it would watch future developments closely.
In Japan, however, personal computer manufacturers are being hit by slackening demand.

Shipments of personal computers in Japan in the April-June period rose an anemic four percent from the same period last year to 1.7 million units, the Japan Electronic Industry Development Association said on Thursday.
This paled in comparison with 51 percent year-on-year growth in the April-June quarter last year.
A spokesman for the industry organisation blamed the waning growth in PC demand in large part on April's increase in the national sales tax.
